title: Hilbert's Fifth Problem
content:
**Hilbert's 5th Problem (1900)**:

> Can Lie's concept of a continuous group of transformations be achieved without the assumption of differentiability?

In modern terms: If G is a topological group acting on a manifold, must G be a **Lie group**?

**Answer (1952): YES!**

Solved by **Gleason**, **Montgomery**, and **Zippin**. Continuous symmetries are automatically smooth.

title: Key Definitions
content:
**Three crucial properties**:

1. **No Small Subgroups**: ‚àÉ neighborhood U of 1 containing no nontrivial subgroups

2. **Locally Euclidean**: Every point has a neighborhood ‚âÖ ‚Ñù‚Åø

3. **Locally Compact**: Every point has a compact neighborhood

These properties characterize when a topological group is a Lie group.

title: Gleason's Lemmas (1952)
content:
**Gleason's Key Contributions**:

**Lemma 1**: A locally compact group with no small subgroups contains a neighborhood of the identity that generates a Lie group.

**Lemma 2**: In a locally compact, locally connected group, every neighborhood of 1 contains an open subgroup.

These lemmas form the technical foundation of the solution.

title: No Small Subgroups Theorem
content:
**Key Insight**: Lie groups have NO small subgroups.

**Why?** Near the identity, a Lie group looks like its **Lie algebra** (a vector space). Vector spaces have no nontrivial bounded subgroups.

The exponential map exp: ùî§ ‚Üí G provides a local diffeomorphism, forcing this property.

**Converse**: Having no small subgroups implies locally Euclidean!

title: Montgomery-Zippin Theorem (1952)
content:
**THE MAIN THEOREM**:

A topological group G is a Lie group if and only if:
1. G is locally compact
2. G has no small subgroups

**Equivalently**: Locally Euclidean topological groups ARE Lie groups.

**This solves Hilbert's 5th Problem**: Continuous symmetries on manifolds are automatically smooth!

The proof spans 100+ pages in Montgomery-Zippin's book.

title: Von Neumann's Theorem (1933)
content:
**First Major Progress**:

Every **compact** topological group has a compatible smooth structure making it a Lie group.

**Proof uses**:
- Peter-Weyl theorem (representation theory)
- Haar measure on compact groups
- Matrix approximation

This was the compact case, 19 years before the full solution.

title: Hilbert-Smith Conjecture
content:
**The Remaining Open Problem**:

If a locally compact group G acts faithfully on a connected n-manifold, is G a Lie group?

**Equivalently**: Can p-adic integers ‚Ñ§‚Çö act faithfully on a manifold?

**Status**:
- ‚úì dim 1, 2: Classical (Montgomery-Zippin 1943)
- ‚úì dim 3: **Pardon (2013)** ‚Äî major breakthrough!
- ‚ùå dim ‚â• 4: **OPEN**

This is the last unsolved part of Hilbert's 5th problem.

title: One-Parameter Subgroups
content:
**One-Parameter Subgroup**: A continuous homomorphism œÜ: ‚Ñù ‚Üí G.

These are the **infinitesimal generators** of group actions.

**In Lie groups**: Every one-parameter subgroup has the form:
$$t \mapsto \exp(tX)$$
for some X in the Lie algebra.

This connects the **Lie algebra** (infinitesimal) to the **Lie group** (global).

title: Consequences
content:
**Deep Implications**:

1. **Smooth = Analytic** for Lie groups (group structure forces analyticity)

2. **Automatic Continuity**: Measurable homomorphisms between Lie groups are automatically smooth!

**Yamabe's Theorem (1953)**:

Every locally compact, connected group G is a projective limit of Lie groups:
$$G = \lim_{\leftarrow} G_i$$

title: Examples & Counterexamples
content:
**Lie Groups**:
- GL(n,‚Ñù), SL(n,‚Ñù), SO(n), U(n) ‚Äî matrix groups

**NOT Lie Groups**:
- Diff(M) ‚Äî diffeomorphism groups (infinite-dimensional)
- ‚Ñ§‚Çö ‚Äî p-adic integers

**Why ‚Ñ§‚Çö fails**:

The p-adic integers have **arbitrarily small open subgroups** (p‚Åø‚Ñ§‚Çö ‚Üí {0}). This violates the "no small subgroups" condition!

title: Historical Summary
content:
**Timeline**:
- **1870s**: Lie founds theory of continuous groups
- **1900**: Hilbert poses the problem
- **1933**: von Neumann solves compact case
- **1952**: Gleason, Montgomery, Zippin solve full problem
- **1953**: Yamabe extends to approximation
- **2013**: Pardon proves dim 3 Hilbert-Smith

**The Answer**: Topology forces smoothness. Continuous symmetries are automatically differentiable!
